text: Ramesh runs a roadside snack stall. After reading the regulations, he realizes he must file Form A with the Registering Authority to obtain a petty food business registration before selling any pakoras.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Submit Form A and pay the registration fee within 7 days of starting the stall.

text: A small dairy cooperative in a town learns that its members who supply all their milk to the co‑op are exempt from the annual inspection requirement.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Keep documentation proving 100 % milk supply to the co‑op to claim the exemption.

text: Priya’s kirana store sells a few packets of oil daily. Because her turnover is under Rs 12 lakhs, she must register as a petty food manufacturer rather than apply for a full licence.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Register under Schedule 4 using the petty‑food route instead of a full licence.

text: The Central Licensing Authority has issued a licence for a large milk‑processing unit. The licence must be displayed on a photo‑ID card at the plant entrance at all times.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Hang the licence card prominently on the entrance wall.

text: A semi‑urban bakery receives a notice that the Registering Authority will inspect its premises within the next 30 days. The owner worries about meeting the hygiene standards in Schedule 4.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Prepare a self‑audit checklist and correct any gaps before the inspection.

text: After obtaining registration, Sunil must renew it before the expiry date. He forgets the deadline and submits the renewal 10 days late. The regulation imposes a Rs 100 per day late fee.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Track renewal dates and submit renewal at least 30 days early to avoid penalties.

text: A food stall owner learns that if his licence is cancelled, he cannot resume business until three months after filing a fresh application.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Maintain compliance to avoid cancellation; keep records of all improvement notices.

text: After a minor violation, the Licensing Authority issues an improvement notice. The owner is given a reasonable hearing before any suspension.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Attend the hearing, present corrective actions, and request a written statement of reasons.

text: A kirana shop in a village wants to expand its product line to include frozen foods. The regulation requires prior approval from the Licensing Authority before changing activities.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Submit a modification request with details of new equipment and obtain written approval.

text: When the owner of a licensed food business dies, the licence does not automatically pass to the heir. The family must apply for a transfer within 90 days.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: File a transfer application with proof of legal heirship before the 90‑day deadline.

text: An electronics retailer mistakenly displays a food licence on its wall, confusing customers. The regulation mandates that only food businesses need to display the licence.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Remove the food licence display from non‑food premises.

text: The Registering Authority can reject an application only after giving the applicant an opportunity to be heard. The shop owner prepares a written objection to the rejection.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Draft a formal objection citing compliance and request reconsideration.

text: A street food vendor must keep a register of the quantity of oil used daily as required by Schedule 4. He worries about the extra paperwork.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Maintain a simple daily log book for oil usage and keep it for inspection.

text: The regulations state that any premises must be located away from polluted areas. A kirana store near a diesel pump wonders if it needs to relocate.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Conduct a risk assessment; if pollution risk is high, seek a relocation permit.

text: The bakery’s floor is uneven and has flaking paint. The regulation requires smooth, easily cleanable floors.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Re‑level the floor and apply a seamless, washable coating before the next inspection.

text: The owner of a small tea stall discovers that metal vessels can cause contamination and must be lined or replaced.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Replace unlined copper pots with stainless‑steel or line them appropriately.

text: A fruit vendor must install insect screens on all windows and doors to meet the pest‑control requirement.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Fit fine mesh screens on all openings and schedule monthly checks.

text: The shop’s hand‑washing sink lacks hot water. The regulation demands hot water for hand hygiene.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Install a small water heater or connect to a hot‑water line for the sink.

text: The owner of a small confectionery learns that all equipment must be designed for easy cleaning and disinfection. He worries about his old wooden slicer.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Replace the wooden slicer with stainless‑steel equipment that can be sanitized.

text: A milk vendor must keep the milk at 4 °C or lower from collection to processing, as mandated by the regulations.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Use a calibrated chilled tank and monitor temperature every hour.

text: A small shop selling packaged snacks must ensure that the packaging material is food‑grade and correctly labelled, or risk licence suspension.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Source food‑grade packaging and verify label compliance before stocking.

text: The regulation requires a technical person with a degree in food technology to supervise production. The owner of a small bakery cannot find such a person locally.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Contract a qualified consultant on a part‑time basis to fulfill the requirement.

text: A kirana store must keep a separate storage area for raw grains away from finished products, as per the segregation rule.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Allocate a dedicated shelf for raw grains and label it clearly.

text: The owner of a small ice‑cream cart learns that ice must be made from potable water and stored in covered containers.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Use a certified ice maker and keep ice bins tightly covered.

text: A street vendor discovers that the law forbids the use of non‑food‑grade plastics for containers that hold ready‑to‑eat items.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Switch to approved food‑grade containers for all ready‑to‑eat foods.

text: The regulation states that a licence fee is non‑refundable under any circumstance. The shop owner is nervous about paying upfront.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Budget the full licence fee before applying to avoid cash‑flow issues.

text: After losing a licence certificate, the owner must apply for a duplicate and pay 10 % of the original fee.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Request a duplicate promptly and include the required 10 % fee payment.

text: A kirana shop that sells dairy products must submit half‑yearly returns (Form D‑2) for milk procurement and sales.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Mark calendar reminders for April‑September and October‑March return deadlines.

text: A small apparel outlet mistakenly advertises “ghee‑free” snacks without a notice board, violating the requirement to display ghee usage.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Put up a visible board listing all items cooked in ghee, butter, or vanaspati.

text: The regulation mandates that any change to the licence‑certified activities must be approved before implementation. A shop wants to add a new snack item.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Submit a change‑request form with details of the new snack and await approval.

text: A bakery must maintain a recall plan that identifies distributors and steps to retrieve a faulty batch. The owner has never prepared such a plan.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Draft a simple recall SOP and keep contact details of all distributors on file.

text: The regulation requires that all food handlers keep fingernails trimmed and clean. The shop’s assistant often has long nails.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Enforce a daily nail‑trimming policy and provide nail‑clippers at the workplace.

text: The owner discovers that smoking and chewing gum are prohibited inside the premises while handling food. He sees staff smoking behind the counter.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Designate a smoking‑free zone and post a sign reminding staff of the rule.

text: The regulations require a designated “Food Safety Officer” to oversee inspections. A small shop has no such officer.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Appoint an existing senior employee as interim Food Safety Officer and train them.

text: A kirana shop must ensure that its drinking water source is potable and, if not, must obtain a chemical and bacteriological test report regularly.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Arrange quarterly water testing from a recognized lab and keep certificates.

text: The regulation specifies that all waste water must be treated or disposed of according to pollution‑control norms. The shop’s drainage leads directly to a nearby open drain.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Connect to the municipal sewage system or install a small effluent treatment unit.

text: A small electronics retailer that occasionally sells packaged snacks must file separate returns for each license class, even though the same owner holds multiple licences.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Maintain distinct record books for each licence category and file individual returns.

text: The shop owner learns that any licence renewal must be applied for at least 30 days before expiry, otherwise the licence lapses. He often forgets the date.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Set calendar alerts 45 days before expiry to prepare the renewal application.

text: A food stall must keep a register of all pesticide‑insecticide applications used for pest control, as required by the regulations. He currently writes them on a loose sheet.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Use a bound register and record date, product, dosage, and location of each application.

text: The law requires that any food business that employs a “technical person” must keep proof of their qualification on file. The shop’s manager has a diploma but no certificate copy.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Scan and archive the technical person’s qualification certificates for inspection.

text: A kirana shop located near a slaughterhouse worries that the foul odour may affect its food items, violating the “sanitary surroundings” clause.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Install air filtration and consider a physical barrier to mitigate odour infiltration.

text: The regulation mandates that all food handlers must wear clean aprons and headcovers. The shop’s staff often work without them.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Provide a set of aprons and caps for each employee and enforce daily use.

text: A small pharmacy that sells health drinks must keep a “recall plan” even though it rarely faces recalls. The owner is unsure what to include.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Draft a simple plan listing steps to notify distributors, remove product, and inform customers.

text: The shop must maintain a daily log of production, raw‑material usage, and sales as per Schedule 4. The owner has no digital system.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Use a spreadsheet or ledger to record quantities each day and back‑up weekly.

text: The regulations require that any change in the licence‑certified capacity (e.g., increasing production from 80 kg to 120 kg per day) must be approved before implementation. The owner plans to expand.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Submit a capacity‑increase application with updated equipment details to the Licensing Authority.

text: A small food processing unit discovers that the regulation forbids the use of cadmium‑containing cookware. Their old pots are made of low‑grade metal.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Replace the old pots with stainless‑steel or food‑grade aluminum alternatives.

text: The regulation mandates that the shop’s premises be “well‑lighted” to enable hygienic work. The owner’s shop has only a single dim bulb.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Install additional LED lighting to achieve at least 540 lux at workstations.

text: A street vendor learns that the licence fee must be paid via bank draft, demand draft, or online transfer as prescribed. He only carries cash.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Open a bank account and arrange for online fee payment to comply with the mode requirement.

text: The regulation requires that the shop keep a “true copy” of the licence displayed at all times. The owner only has a photocopy.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Obtain an official printed copy from the authority and replace the photocopy.

text: A small bakery must ensure that all containers holding food are covered with lids or clean gauze to prevent contamination. The owner sometimes leaves open bowls on the counter.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Use fitted lids or clean cloth covers for all open containers during operation.

text: The regulation states that “no person shall manufacture, store or expose for sale any article of food in premises not effectively separated from privy, urinal, or waste.” The shop’s storage room shares a wall with the bathroom.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Build a partition or relocate food storage away from sanitary facilities.

text: A kirana store must ensure that all workers with infectious diseases are not allowed to handle food. The owner is unsure how to verify health status.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Require medical certificates for all food‑handling staff and keep them on file.

text: The regulation requires that all food handlers wash hands with soap before starting work and after using the toilet. The shop’s sink lacks soap dispensers.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Install wall‑mounted soap dispensers and post hand‑washing reminders.

text: The shop must keep a “register of sales” indicating the nature and quantity of each food item sold, as part of the recall requirement. The owner tracks only cash totals.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Start a simple sales ledger noting product name, batch number, and quantity sold each day.

text: A small dairy unit must submit an annual recall plan that includes contact details of distributors. The owner has no distributor list.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Compile a spreadsheet of all distributors with phone numbers and email addresses.

text: The regulation requires that the licence be renewed for a period of 1–5 years as chosen by the operator. The shop owner is unsure which period is optimal.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Choose a 3‑year term to balance stability and flexibility, then apply for renewal accordingly.

text: A street food vendor discovers that the regulation forbids the sale of irradiated food unless a special licence is obtained. He occasionally sells imported canned fish that may be irradiated.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Verify product status; if irradiated, cease sale or apply for the specific irradiation licence.

text: The shop must maintain a “clean‑in‑place” (CIP) system for equipment that is required under Schedule 4. The owner has a manual cleaning routine only.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Install a CIP system for high‑risk equipment or document a validated manual cleaning procedure.

text: The regulation requires that any “food business operator” display a notice board listing all items cooked in ghee, edible oil, vanaspati, etc., for consumer information. The shop has never displayed such a board.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Create and hang a clear board near the serving area listing all ghee‑based items.

text: A kirana store must keep a register of the source and quality of all raw materials, as per Schedule 4. The owner buys spices from multiple vendors without records.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Maintain a supplier log with purchase date, batch number, and quality certificates.

text: The regulation states that the shop must have a “designated officer” not below the rank of Sub‑Divisional Officer to oversee food safety in the district. The owner wonders who this is.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Contact the local District Food Safety Office to identify the designated officer.

text: A small vendor learns that any change in the licence‑certified activity must be communicated before the change occurs, otherwise the licence may be suspended. He wants to add a new beverage line.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: File a change‑notification form describing the new beverage before starting production.

text: The regulation requires that the shop keep a “record of water testing” if potable water is supplied from a borewell. The owner uses a borewell but has never tested the water.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Send a water sample to a recognized lab quarterly and retain the test reports.

text: A food stall must ensure that all “food‑grade” packaging material is used and that non‑food‑grade plastics are not employed. The owner occasionally uses cheap plastic bags.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Replace cheap bags with certified food‑grade packaging and keep purchase receipts.

text: The regulation mandates that the shop have a “clean drinking water supply” for both processing and personal use. The vendor’s tap water sometimes smells of chlorine.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Install a point‑of‑use filtration system and test water monthly.

text: A small bakery must keep a “record of pest‑control measures” including dates and chemicals used, as required by Schedule 4. The owner currently relies on occasional sprays without documentation.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Adopt a monthly pest‑control schedule and log each activity with product name and dosage.

text: The regulations require that all “food‑handling areas” be separated from “non‑food areas” such as staff restrooms. The shop’s break room opens directly onto the preparation area.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Install a physical partition or relocate the break room away from the food‑handling zone.

text: The shop must have “adequate ventilation” to prevent the flow of air from dirty to clean areas. The owner’s kitchen has a single exhaust fan that often malfunctions.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Repair or upgrade the exhaust system to ensure proper airflow direction.

text: The regulation requires that “all equipment and utensils” be of corrosion‑free material and easy to clean. The vendor still uses wooden chopping boards.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Replace wooden boards with food‑grade plastic or stainless‑steel alternatives.

text: The licence fee for a petty food business is Rs 100, while a larger unit may pay up to Rs 5,000. The owner worries about paying the higher fee for a modest increase in capacity.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Calculate expected turnover and choose the licence category that matches the fee schedule.

text: A small food processor must submit a “self‑attested declaration of adherence to basic hygiene” with the registration application. The owner is unsure what to include.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Draft a declaration covering cleanliness, water quality, pest control, and staff hygiene, then sign it.

text: The regulation allows a “single licence” to cover multiple articles of food and multiple premises in the same local area, such as a milk cooperative and its collection points. The shop owner wants to know if his multiple stalls can share one licence.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Apply for a combined licence covering all stalls within the same locality.

text: The law requires that the “food business operator shall not manufacture, store or expose for sale any article of food in premises not effectively separated from privy, urinal, or waste.” The owner’s storage room is adjacent to a communal toilet.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Relocate storage to a different room or construct a sealed barrier between it and the toilet.

text: The regulation mandates that all “food handlers” avoid wearing false nails or loose jewellery. The shop’s assistant wears a silver bracelet.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Enforce a dress‑code that prohibits jewellery while handling food.

text: A small retailer must keep a “record of temperature control” for all cold‑storage units, ensuring that milk is stored at ≤ 4 °C. The shop uses a basic refrigerator without a temperature log.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Place a digital thermometer in the fridge and record readings twice daily.

text: The regulations require that “any vehicle used to transport foods must be clean and maintain required temperature.” The vendor’s motorbike is often dusty.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Clean the bike daily and use insulated carriers to keep foods at safe temperatures.

text: The shop must maintain “adequate facilities for hand washing” with hot and cold water and proper drying means. The vendor only has a single faucet with no hand‑dryer.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Install a second faucet with a soap dispenser and provide disposable paper towels.

text: The regulation specifies that “all licences shall be issued within 60 days of application ID issuance.” The owner’s application has been pending for 75 days.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Send a formal reminder to the Licensing Authority citing the statutory 60‑day deadline.

text: The law requires that “any person or agency authorized for inspection may issue a notice guiding the operator to make necessary changes.” The shop receives such a notice but is unclear about the required actions.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Prepare a written action plan addressing each point and submit it within 30 days.

text: A small food processor must have at least one “technical person” with a degree in Food Technology or related field. The owner only has a high‑school graduate.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Hire a part‑time qualified consultant to fulfill the technical person requirement.

text: The regulation mandates that “any change that alters information on the licence certificate shall require prior approval.” The shop wants to change its address on the licence.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Submit an amendment request with proof of new address and pay the one‑year fee.

text: The shop must ensure that “no food other than that indicated in the licence is produced.” The owner occasionally improvises a new snack without updating the licence.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Add the new snack to the licence through a formal amendment before producing it.

text: The regulation requires that “all food business operators shall keep a record of raw‑material procurement source.” The vendor sources spices from a local market with no invoices.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Request written receipts from market sellers and store them for inspection.

text: The shop must display a “true copy of the licence” at a prominent place in the premises at all times. The owner keeps it hidden in a drawer.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Mount the licence on the wall near the cash counter where customers can see it.

text: A small retailer must ensure that “all equipment shall be placed well away from walls to allow proper inspection.” The owner’s mixers are tucked into a corner.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Rearrange the shop layout so that each machine has at least 30 cm clearance on all sides.

text: The regulation requires that “all waste water must be treated or disposed of according to the pollution‑control board.” The shop drains directly into a nearby stream.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Connect to the municipal sewer or install a small grease trap and settle tank.

text: The shop must maintain “a register of medical fitness certificates of all food handlers.” The owner has no such certificates.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Arrange a medical check‑up for each staff member and file the certificates.

text: The regulation mandates “annual food safety inspection” for all registered establishments. The owner worries about being caught without a recent audit.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Schedule a pre‑inspection self‑audit six months before the due date.

text: The shop must keep a “record of temperature control during transportation” for perishable goods. The vendor transports milk in a basic cooler without temperature logs.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Use a portable data logger in the cooler and record temperatures for each trip.

text: The regulation states that “any food business operator shall not sell food in premises that are not effectively separated from urinals or waste.” The shop’s food display is directly above a shared bathroom.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Relocate the display to a different wall or install a solid barrier between it and the bathroom.

text: A small bakery must ensure that “all lighting fixtures in food‑handling areas are safety‑type and protected.” The shop uses exposed bulb sockets.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Replace exposed sockets with sealed, waterproof fixtures suitable for wet areas.

text: The regulation requires “cleaning chemicals must be stored separately from food items in clearly labeled containers.” The vendor keeps detergent bottles on the same shelf as spices.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Install a locked cabinet for cleaning agents away from food storage.

text: The shop must keep a “record of pest‑control chemicals, dates, and frequency.” The owner only writes “sprayed” on a sticky note.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Use a pre‑printed logbook to note product name, concentration, date, and area treated.

text: A small food stall must ensure that “no smoking, chewing, or spitting is allowed in the premises.” The owner notices customers chewing betel leaf near the counter.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Post a “No Chewing/Smoking” sign and politely ask customers to comply.

text: The regulation requires that “all food‑handling surfaces be smooth, non‑porous, and easy to clean.” The shop uses cracked tiles on the floor.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Replace cracked tiles with seamless, washable flooring material.

text: The shop must have “adequate drainage” to prevent water pooling. The vendor’s sink often overflows during peak hours.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Upgrade the sink drain to a larger pipe and install an overflow alarm.

text: The regulation mandates “a display board with do’s & don’ts for workers” in the premises. The shop currently has no such board.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Create a simple poster with hygiene rules and hang it near the staff entrance.

text: A small retailer must ensure “no animal or bird can enter the food preparation area.” The vendor’s shop has an open window without a screen.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Fit fine‑mesh screens on all windows and doors.

text: The regulation requires that “all equipment used for food must not impart metallic contamination.” The shop’s old metal grinder sometimes leaves metal shavings.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Replace the grinder with a food‑grade stainless‑steel model.

text: The shop must keep “a register of all raw‑material receipts, including batch numbers and dates.” The owner only notes the total quantity purchased.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Record each purchase with supplier name, batch/lot number, and receipt date in a ledger.

text: The regulation states that “any licence holder must display the licence on a photo‑ID card.” The owner has only a printed copy.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Request a photo‑ID card from the Licensing Authority and display it prominently.

text: A small confectionery must ensure “temperature control for chocolate tempering” to avoid spoilage. The shop lacks a calibrated thermometer.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Purchase a digital thermometer and log tempering temperatures for each batch.

text: The regulation requires “all food business operators to submit an annual return (Form D‑1) by May.” The shop misses the deadline and faces a penalty.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Set a yearly reminder for April 15 to prepare and submit Form D‑1 before May.

text: The shop must keep “a record of cleaning schedules for equipment and premises.” The owner cleans irregularly and has no schedule.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Draft a weekly cleaning checklist and sign off after each task.

text: The regulation mandates “that all food handlers must wear clean aprons and headcovers.” The vendor’s staff sometimes work without aprons.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Provide a fresh apron and headcover for each shift and enforce its use.

text: A small shop must ensure “that no food is stored in containers made of cadmium‑containing material.” The owner uses cheap metal tins for sweets.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Switch to food‑grade stainless‑steel or glass containers for storage.

text: The regulation requires “a licence to be valid for 1–5 years as chosen by the operator.” The owner initially chose a 1‑year term and now faces frequent renewal paperwork.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Apply for a longer licence term (e.g., 3 years) to reduce renewal frequency.

text: The shop must “maintain a register of all pest‑control chemicals used, with dates and quantities.” The owner only keeps receipts.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Create a simple table listing each chemical, batch number, date applied, and amount used.

text: The regulation states that “any change in the licence‑certified activity must be communicated before the change occurs.” The owner adds a new ready‑to‑eat salad without notifying the authority.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Submit a formal change request describing the new salad line before production begins.

text: The shop must ensure “all water used for washing raw materials is potable.” The vendor sometimes uses water from a nearby pond.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Install a filtration system and only use treated water for washing foods.

text: The regulation requires “that all food handlers avoid touching their face or hair while handling food.” The staff often rubs their eyes.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Conduct brief training on hand hygiene and provide disposable gloves.

text: A small retailer must “maintain a register of raw‑material procurement source, including supplier details.” The owner buys spices from a market stall with no formal name.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Record the stall owner’s name, location, and contact number for each purchase.

text: The regulation mandates “that all equipment be placed well away from walls for inspection.” The shop’s deep‑fryer is flush against the wall.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Re‑position the fryer to allow at least 30 cm clearance on all sides.

text: The shop must keep “a record of any food‑borne disease incidents among staff.” The owner has never documented a single case.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Start a health incident register and note dates, symptoms, and actions taken.

text: A small food stall must ensure “no animal waste or foul matter is stored near food.” The vendor keeps a bucket of waste under the counter.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Relocate waste containers to a separate, covered area away from the preparation zone.

text: The regulation requires “all food‑handling personnel to be medically fit.” The owner’s assistant has a chronic cough but continues to work.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Obtain a medical fitness certificate for the assistant and reassign them away from food handling.

text: The shop must “display a notice board containing separate lists of articles cooked in ghee, oil, or vanaspati.” The owner has never prepared such a board.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Create a simple chart listing each item and the fat used; hang it near the serving counter.

text: The regulation mandates “that all food business operators shall not sell food items that have not been approved for safety.” The vendor plans to introduce a new spice blend not listed in any standard.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Seek approval from the Food Safety Authority before launching the new spice blend.

text: A small retailer must “maintain a register of all food safety audits and their outcomes.” The shop has never been audited.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Schedule an internal audit quarterly and log findings in a dedicated notebook.

text: The regulation requires “that all food containers be covered or sealed to protect from dust and insects.” The vendor leaves open bowls of chutney on the counter.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Use lidded containers or cover bowls with clean cloths when not being served.

text: The shop must “ensure that the water used for cleaning is potable and, if required, tested chemically and bacteriologically.” The owner never tests the water.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Send water samples to a certified lab twice a year and keep the reports.

text: The regulation mandates “that all food handlers must wash hands with soap before and after using the toilet.” The shop’s hand‑washing station lacks soap.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Install a soap dispenser and ensure it is refilled daily.

text: A small food business must “maintain a register of all recall actions taken.” The owner has never recalled a product.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Prepare a simple recall log template and fill it out if a recall ever occurs.

text: The regulation requires “that all food‑handling equipment be made of corrosion‑free material.” The shop’s metal shelves rust in the humid season.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Replace rusted shelves with stainless‑steel or coated alternatives.

text: The shop must “maintain a record of all temperature‑controlled storage units.” The owner only has a handwritten note of the fridge temperature.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Install a digital temperature logger and export daily readings.

text: The regulation mandates “that all food business operators shall ensure that no product other than that indicated in the licence is produced.” The vendor occasionally sells a homemade jam not listed.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Apply for an amendment to the licence before producing the jam.

text: A small retailer must “ensure that all waste water disposal complies with the State Pollution Control Board.” The shop drains directly into a nearby ditch.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Connect to the municipal sewer or install a small septic tank approved by the board.

text: The regulation requires “that all food business operators display a true copy of the licence at a prominent place.” The owner keeps the licence in a drawer.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Mount the licence on the wall near the entrance where customers can see it.

text: The shop must “maintain a register of all medical fitness certificates of food handlers.” The owner has no such register.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Create a binder for each staff member’s certificate and update it annually.

text: The regulation mandates “that all food business operators shall have a designated officer to oversee compliance.” The shop has no such officer.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Appoint an experienced senior employee as interim compliance officer.

text: The shop must “ensure that all containers used for cleaning chemicals are clearly labelled.” The owner stores detergent in a reused food jar.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Transfer chemicals to dedicated, labeled containers and keep them separate from food items.

text: The regulation requires “that all food handlers be provided with clean protective clothing.” The vendor’s staff uses their own dirty clothes.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Supply each worker with a fresh apron and cap for each shift.

text: A small retailer must “maintain a record of any improvement notices issued and the actions taken.” The owner never documents the notice.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Create a logbook to record notice dates, required actions, and completion dates.

text: The regulation mandates “that any licence suspension must be recorded with reasons and communicated to the operator.” The shop receives a suspension without a written reason.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Request a written statement of reasons from the licensing authority immediately.

text: The shop must “ensure that all food‑handling surfaces are cleaned with effective disinfectant.” The vendor uses only water to wipe counters.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Adopt a routine that uses a registered food‑grade disinfectant after each cleaning.

text: A small food outlet must “maintain a register of all raw‑material receipts, including batch numbers.” The owner only notes the total weight of flour purchased.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Record supplier name, batch/lot number, and receipt date for each flour purchase.

text: The regulation requires “that all food‑handling staff wash hands with soap before starting work and after using the toilet.” The shop’s staff sometimes skip hand‑washing.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Place visual reminders at the sink and enforce a sign‑off before each shift.

text: The shop must “ensure that all food containers are covered to prevent contamination.” The vendor leaves open jars of pickles on the shelf.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Use airtight lids or clean cloth covers for all open jars when not being served.

text: The regulation mandates “that all equipment be placed well away from walls for inspection.” The shop’s dough mixer is flush against the wall.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Re‑arrange the layout to provide at least 30 cm clearance around the mixer.

text: A small retailer must “maintain a register of all pest‑control activities, including dates and chemicals used.” The owner only writes “sprayed” on a scrap paper.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Use a pre‑printed pest‑control logbook to capture detailed information each time.

text: The regulation requires “that any change in the licence‑certified activity be approved before implementation.” The shop adds a new fried snack without approval.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Submit a formal amendment request describing the new snack before selling it.

text: The shop must “ensure that all water used for food preparation is potable.” The vendor sometimes uses rainwater stored in a barrel.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Treat rainwater with filtration and disinfection before using it for food.

text: The regulation mandates “that all food handlers avoid touching their face while working.” The staff frequently rubs their eyes.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Conduct brief hygiene training and post reminder signs near workstations.

text: A small shop must “maintain a record of any food‑borne disease incidents among employees.” The owner has never logged a single case.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Start a health incident register noting date, symptoms, and actions taken.

text: The regulation requires “that all food‑handling areas be separate from waste disposal zones.” The vendor’s trash bin is placed next to the cooking table.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Relocate the trash bin to a covered area at least 2 m away from food preparation.

text: The shop must “ensure that all employees are medically fit for food handling.” The owner discovers a worker with a contagious skin infection.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Require a medical certificate and reassign the worker away from food contact.

text: The regulation mandates “that all food containers be made of non‑toxic material and not impart taste.” The vendor uses low‑grade plastic tubs for sweets.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Replace plastic tubs with food‑grade BPA‑free containers.

text: A small retailer must “display a notice board listing items cooked in ghee, oil, or vanaspati.” The shop has never displayed such a board.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Create a simple board with each item and the fat used; place it near the ordering counter.

text: The regulation requires “that all food‑handling staff wash hands with soap before and after using the restroom.” The shop’s sink lacks a hand‑dryer.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Install paper‑towel dispensers or a hand‑drying machine next to the sink.

text: The shop must “maintain a register of raw‑material procurement, including source and quality certificates.” The vendor buys spices from a local market without certificates.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Request certificates from suppliers and file them in a procurement binder.

text: The regulation mandates “that all food business operators keep a record of any recall actions taken.” The shop has never recalled a product but wants to be prepared.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Draft a recall SOP template and keep it ready for immediate use.

text: The shop must “ensure that all equipment is corrosion‑free and easy to clean.” The vendor’s metal grinder shows rust spots.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Replace the rusted grinder with a stainless‑steel model.

text: The regulation requires “that all food handlers avoid wearing false nails or loose jewellery.” The staff often wears rings while handling dough.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Enforce a no‑jewellery rule during food preparation and provide band‑aids for necessary medical wear.

text: A small retailer must “maintain a register of temperature logs for all cold‑storage units.” The owner writes temperatures on a loose sheet that gets lost.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Use a bound logbook or digital app to record and back up temperature data daily.

text: The regulation mandates “that all food‑handling areas have adequate ventilation and airflow from clean to dirty zones.” The shop’s kitchen exhaust is blocked.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Clean or repair the exhaust fan to ensure proper airflow direction.

text: The shop must “ensure that all cleaning chemicals are stored separately from food items.” The vendor keeps bleach in the same cabinet as spices.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Relocate cleaning agents to a locked, labelled cabinet away from food storage.

text: The regulation requires “that all food handlers wash hands with soap before handling food and after any restroom use.” The staff sometimes skips washing due to rush.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Install a timer at the sink to ensure a minimum 20‑second wash and monitor compliance.

text: A small retailer must “maintain a register of all pest‑control chemicals, dates, and quantities used.” The owner only notes “pesticide used” without details.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Use a detailed logbook capturing product name, batch, dosage, and application area.

text: The regulation mandates “that all food‑handling surfaces be smooth, non‑porous, and easy to clean.” The shop’s wooden chopping board shows cracks.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Replace the wooden board with a food‑grade plastic or stainless‑steel cutting board.

text: The shop must “ensure that all water used for washing raw materials is potable and tested.” The vendor uses water from a communal well without testing.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Submit water samples to a lab quarterly and keep the certificates on file.

text: The regulation requires “that any licence holder display the licence at a prominent place at all times.” The owner keeps the licence in a file cabinet.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Mount the licence on the wall near the cash counter where customers can see it.

text: A small food stall must “keep a register of all raw‑material receipts with batch numbers.” The vendor only records the total weight of rice purchased.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Write down supplier name, batch/lot number, and receipt date for each rice purchase.

text: The regulation mandates “that all food business operators have a technical person with a degree in food technology.” The shop lacks such a person.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Hire a part‑time consultant with the required qualification to fulfill the role.

text: The shop must “ensure that all food handlers are medically fit and free from infectious diseases.” The owner discovers a worker with a skin infection.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Require a medical clearance before allowing the worker to return to food contact duties.

text: The regulation requires “that all equipment be placed away from walls to allow proper inspection and cleaning.” The vendor’s deep‑fryer is flush against the wall.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Move the fryer to provide at least 30 cm clearance on all sides.

text: A small retailer must “maintain a register of all pest‑control activities, including dates and chemicals used.” The owner keeps only receipts.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Use a dedicated logbook to record each pest‑control event with full details.

text: The regulation mandates “that all food‑handling staff avoid smoking, chewing, and spitting in the premises.” The vendor often sees staff smoking near the counter.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Designate a smoking area away from the shop and enforce the rule.

text: The shop must “ensure that all containers used for food are covered to prevent contamination.” The owner leaves open jars of pickle on the shelf.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Use airtight lids or clean cloth covers for all open jars when not being served.

text: The regulation requires “that all water used for cleaning be hot enough for disinfection.” The vendor’s sink water never exceeds 40 °C.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Install a water heater set to at least 65 °C for cleaning purposes.

text: A small food business must “maintain a record of any recall actions and the distributors contacted.” The owner has never documented a recall.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Prepare a recall log template and fill it out if a recall ever occurs.

text: The regulation mandates “that all food handlers wash hands with soap before starting work and after using the toilet.” The shop lacks soap dispensers.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Install wall‑mounted soap dispensers at each hand‑washing station.

text: The shop must “ensure that all equipment is made of corrosion‑free material and easy to clean.” The vendor’s metal ladle shows rust.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Replace the rusted ladle with a stainless‑steel version.

text: The regulation requires “that all food‑handling areas have adequate ventilation to prevent steam and odour buildup.” The shop’s kitchen has poor airflow.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Install an additional exhaust fan or improve existing ventilation ducts.

text: A small retailer must “maintain a register of all raw‑material receipts, including source and batch numbers.” The owner only notes the total quantity of oil bought.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Record supplier name, batch/lot number, and purchase date for each oil delivery.

text: The regulation mandates “that all food handlers avoid wearing false nails or loose jewellery.” The staff frequently wear bracelets while preparing snacks.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Enforce a dress code prohibiting jewellery during food handling.

text: The shop must “ensure that all waste water is treated or disposed of according to local pollution‑control board standards.” The vendor drains directly into a nearby stream.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Connect to the municipal sewer system or install a small septic tank approved by the board.

text: The regulation requires “that all food‑handling surfaces be smooth and non‑porous.” The vendor’s countertop has cracks and stains.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Replace the countertop with a seamless, washable material like stainless steel.

text: A small shop must “maintain a register of all medical fitness certificates of food handlers.” The owner has no such register.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Create a binder and file each employee’s certificate, updating annually.

text: The regulation mandates “that all food business operators display a true copy of the licence at a prominent place.” The shop’s licence is hidden in a drawer.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Mount the licence on a visible wall near the entrance.

text: The shop must “ensure that all cleaning chemicals are stored separately from food items.” The vendor keeps detergent bottles on the same shelf as spices.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Relocate all cleaning agents to a locked cabinet away from food shelves.

text: The regulation requires “that all food handlers wash hands with soap before handling food and after restroom use.” The staff often skips washing due to time pressure.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Install visual timers and monitor compliance with spot checks.

text: A small retailer must “maintain a register of all pest‑control chemicals used, with dates and quantities.” The owner only writes “sprayed” on a sticky note.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Use a printed logbook to capture chemical name, batch, dosage, date, and treated area.

text: The regulation mandates “that all food‑handling equipment be made of corrosion‑free material.” The vendor’s metal ladle is rusted.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Replace the ladle with a stainless‑steel version and inspect regularly.

text: The shop must “ensure that all food handlers avoid smoking, chewing, or spitting in the premises.” The owner sees staff chewing betel leaf near the counter.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Post a “No Chewing” sign and remind staff of the rule during shifts.

text: The regulation requires “that all food containers be covered to prevent dust and insects.” The vendor leaves open jars of chutney on the shelf.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Use airtight lids or cover jars with clean cloth when not serving.

text: A small food stall must “maintain a register of raw‑material receipts, including batch numbers and dates.” The owner only notes the total quantity of flour bought.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Record supplier name, batch/lot number, and receipt date for each flour purchase.

text: The regulation mandates “that all equipment be placed well away from walls for easy inspection.” The shop’s mixer is flush against the wall.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Rearrange the floor plan to provide at least 30 cm clearance around the mixer.

text: The shop must “ensure that all water used for cleaning is hot enough for disinfection.” The sink water never exceeds 45 °C.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Install a water heater set to a minimum of 65 °C for cleaning purposes.

text: The regulation requires “that all food business operators maintain a register of any recall actions taken.” The owner has never prepared such a register.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Create a simple recall log template and keep it ready for any future incident.

text: A small retailer must “maintain a register of pest‑control activities with dates and chemicals used.” The vendor only notes “sprayed” on scrap paper.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Use a bound logbook to record detailed pest‑control information each time.

text: The regulation mandates “that all food‑handling staff wash hands with soap before starting work and after restroom use.” The shop lacks soap at the sink.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Install a soap dispenser and ensure it is refilled daily.

text: The shop must “ensure that all cleaning chemicals are stored in clearly labelled containers separate from food.” The vendor keeps detergent in a reused spice jar.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Transfer chemicals to dedicated, labelled containers and store them away from food.

text: The regulation requires “that all food handlers avoid wearing false nails or loose jewellery.” The staff often wears rings while preparing dough.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Enforce a no‑jewellery policy during food handling and provide ring‑free alternatives.

text: A small food stall must “maintain a register of raw‑material receipts with batch numbers.” The owner only records total weight of sugar purchased.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Log supplier name, batch/lot number, and purchase date for each sugar delivery.

text: The regulation mandates “that all food‑handling areas have adequate lighting of at least 540 lux at inspection points.” The shop’s lighting is dim and uneven.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Install LED fixtures to achieve the required lux level throughout the preparation area.

text: The shop must “ensure that all equipment is made of non‑toxic material and does not impart taste.” The vendor uses old plastic containers that may leach chemicals.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Replace old plastic containers with BPA‑free, food‑grade options.

text: The regulation requires “that all food business operators keep a register of any improvement notices and corrective actions taken.” The owner has never documented such notices.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Start a logbook to capture notice dates, required actions, and completion status.

text: A small retailer must “maintain a record of all raw‑material procurement sources, including supplier details.” The vendor buys spices from a street stall without receipts.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Note the stall owner’s name, location, and contact number for each purchase.

text: The regulation mandates “that all food handlers wash hands with soap before handling food and after restroom use.” The staff sometimes skips washing due to rush.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Place visual reminders and conduct random checks to ensure compliance.

text: The shop must “ensure that all waste water is treated or disposed of as per pollution‑control norms.” The vendor drains directly into a nearby ditch.
source: FOOD SAFETY AND STANDARDS (LICENSING AND REGISTRATION OF FOODBUSINESSES), REGULATIONS 2011
decision_or_recommendation: Connect to a municipal sewage line or install a small effluent treatment unit.

text: Ravi runs a kirana store in urban Delhi. His annual turnover reaches ₹12 lakh, so he must register for GST before the next month. @12
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Apply for GST registration within 30 days of crossing the ₹10 lakh limit.

text: Meena’s small tea stall supplies only tea and snacks. She opts for the composition scheme and pays 1 % of turnover as tax, avoiding detailed returns. @117
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Choose the composition levy if turnover ≤ ₹50 lakh and maintain a simple quarterly return.

text: A local electronics dealer buys a batch of LED lights from an unregistered supplier. Under reverse charge, he must self‑assess tax and cannot claim input credit until he pays it. @109
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Record the purchase, self‑assess GST, and pay it to claim the input credit later.

text: The owner of a pharmacy issues a tax invoice only after receiving payment because the invoice amount exceeds ₹1,000 and the supplier prefers cash. @143
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Issue the tax invoice at the earlier of invoice date or payment receipt, as required.

text: A clothing boutique sells a bundle of shirts, belts, and ties for a single price. The tax is levied on the highest‑rate item in the mixed supply. @107
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Identify the highest‑taxed item in the bundle and apply that rate to the whole sale.

text: A grocery shop receives a delivery of rice on credit. The supplier’s GST invoice arrives later, so the shop can claim input credit only after the invoice is uploaded. @176
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Ensure the supplier’s tax invoice is received and entered before the due date for claiming credit.

text: A small bakery makes continuous supplies of bread daily. The time of supply is deemed the date of each invoice, not the day of production. @34
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Issue a tax invoice for each day’s batch to establish the correct time of supply.

text: A mobile‑phone dealer sells a phone with a free protective case. Because the case is a complimentary accessory, it is treated as part of the principal supply for tax purposes. @90
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Treat bundled free items as part of the principal supply when calculating GST.

text: Arjun supplies spices to Maharashtra. He must register because he makes inter‑state sales.
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Register for GST before the next filing period.

text: Sunita keeps her kirana ledger on paper. The law now requires an electronic credit ledger.
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Migrate records to the prescribed e‑credit system.

text: Vikram buys a delivery van for personal use. GST credit on that vehicle is blocked.
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Do not claim input credit for personal‑use motor vehicles.

text: A farmer sells fresh produce at a local market. He is exempt from GST registration.
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Continue operating without GST registration.

text: An online gadget shop ships items through a marketplace. The platform must collect tax at source.
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Ensure the platform registers as a tax collector.

text: Priya provides consulting services and invoices after the project ends. Time of supply follows the invoice date.
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Issue the tax invoice promptly to fix the supply date.

text: The pharmacy must file its annual GST return by 31 Dec each year.
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Mark 31 Dec as a non‑negotiable filing date.

text: Ravi missed the September return deadline. He now faces a daily late fee.
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Pay the pending fee immediately to stop accrual.

text: The boutique stores invoices for five years. The law requires retention for 72 months.
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Archive all records for at least six years.

text: A large wholesale dealer exceeds ₹1 crore turnover. An audit is now mandatory.
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Appoint a chartered accountant for the statutory audit.

text: Meena’s shop registration is cancelled. She must settle tax on remaining stock.
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Compute and pay tax on inventory before deregistration.

text: New owners must provide Aadhaar to obtain GST registration.
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Submit Aadhaar proof during the registration process.

text: A manufacturer sends inputs to a job worker. The principal can claim credit on those inputs.
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Record the transfer and claim input credit as prescribed.

text: The Input Service Distributor must allocate credit based on each recipient’s turnover.
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Use the turnover‑ratio method for credit allocation.

text: A casual trader starts a weekend stall. He must deposit advance tax before beginning.
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Pay the estimated tax deposit prior to the first sale.

text: A non‑resident software exporter needs a Unique Identity Number to register.
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Apply for a UIN using the prescribed documents.

text: A food packer includes insurance in the sale price. The whole bundle is taxed as a composite supply.
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Apply the GST rate of the principal food supply to the bundle.

text: Two companies merge. Their unused input credit can be transferred to the new entity.
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: File the prescribed notice to move the credit to the merged firm.

text: A retailer purchases diesel for his generator. GST on diesel is payable on reverse charge.
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Self‑assess GST on diesel and record it as input credit.

text: The government announces an exemption for certain medical devices. The shop must update its tax schedule.
source: THE CENTRAL GOODS AND SERVICES TAX ACT, 2017
decision_or_recommendation: Verify the exemption list and stop charging GST on those devices.
